messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Alan B.- Milt's Hikone bori tsuba mei.
messages.msgSnippet: Cary, Thanks. Alan ... From: Cary Condell  To:  Sent: Saturday, August 23, 2003 10:07 AM Subject:
messages.messageBody:
Cary,
Thanks.
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: "Cary Condell" <condell@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Saturday, August 23, 2003 10:07 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Alan B.- Milt's Hikone bori tsuba mei.


: Alan,
: If you have the Kinko Jiten handy (Heisei 11 ed.)
: check the Mokuji (table of contents) page 42, bottom
: for Milt's first character.
: Sakusha recorded from page 209.
:
: Reading given is Yoshi or Nobu (kunyomi) or Gi (onyomi).
: This is new Nelsons #1317.
: Eight strokes.
:
: This is not to be confused with the Sen (onyomi)
: Nobu (kunyomi) character on page 29, bottom.
: This is new Nelson's #1328.
: Nine strokes.
: Sakusha recorded from page 920.
:
: Cary Condell
:
: Condell & Co., Ltd.
: P.O. Box 590115
: San Francisco, CA 94159
:
: Tel. 415-751-3784
:
: condell@...
: http://www.ikkyudo.com
: alan bale wrote:
:
: > Cary,
: > Isn't the 'yoshi' kanji missing one horizontal stroke that it needs to
be
: > read 'nobu'?
: > Alan
: > ----- Original Message -----
: > From: "Cary Condell" <condell@...>
: > To: <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>; <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
: > Sent: Saturday, August 23, 2003 3:17 AM
: > Subject: [nihontostudy] Milt - Hikone bori tsuba mei.
: >
: >

: > : or Yoshimichi saku. In either case this mei is
: > : unrecorded in the Kinko Jiten, Wakayama (rev. Heisei 11).
: > :
: > : I'll try the fuchi mei tomorrow.
: > :
: > : Cary Condell
: > :

messages.subject: Alan B.- Milt's Hikone bori tsuba mei.
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, If you have the Kinko Jiten handy (Heisei 11 ed.) check the Mokuji (table of contents) page 42, bottom for Milt s first character. Sakusha recorded from
messages.messageBody:
Alan,
If you have the Kinko Jiten handy (Heisei 11 ed.)
check the Mokuji (table of contents) page 42, bottom
for Milt's first character.
Sakusha recorded from page 209.

Reading given is Yoshi or Nobu (kunyomi) or Gi (onyomi).
This is new Nelsons #1317.
Eight strokes.

This is not to be confused with the Sen (onyomi)
Nobu (kunyomi) character on page 29, bottom.
This is new Nelson's #1328.
Nine strokes.
Sakusha recorded from page 920.

Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com

messages.msgSnippet: Cary, Isn t the yoshi kanji missing one horizontal stroke that it needs to be read nobu ? Alan ... From: Cary Condell  To:
messages.messageBody:
Cary,
Isn't the 'yoshi' kanji missing one horizontal stroke that it needs to be
read 'nobu'?
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: "Cary Condell" <condell@...>
To: <nihonto@yahoogroups.com>; <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>

: or Yoshimichi saku. In either case this mei is
: unrecorded in the Kinko Jiten, Wakayama (rev. Heisei 11).
:

messages.subject: Milt - Hikone bori tsuba mei.
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, Milt... Hikone bori tsuba mei can be read Nobumichi saku or Yoshimichi saku. In either case this mei is unrecorded in the Kinko Jiten, Wakayama (rev.
messages.messageBody:
Alan, Milt...
Hikone bori tsuba mei can be read Nobumichi saku
or Yoshimichi saku. In either case this mei is
unrecorded in the Kinko Jiten, Wakayama (rev. Heisei 11).

I'll try the fuchi mei tomorrow.

Cary Condell

Condell & Co., Ltd.
P.O. Box 590115
San Francisco, CA 94159

Tel. 415-751-3784

condell@...
http://www.ikkyudo.com
